title: 106_hr2261
content: The "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999" is introduced, which includes a credit for health insurance costs of previously uninsured individuals and individuals with COBRA coverage under section 25B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999" introduces a tax credit for individuals who pay for qualified health insurance coverage for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. The credit is equal to 60% of the amount paid, with monthly limitations based on the type of coverage. The tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage is $2,400 for family coverage. An eligible month is defined as starting at least 1 year after the individual was eligible for or participated in a group health plan providing qualified health insurance. For joint returns, a month is eligible only if both spouses qualify. Amounts paid for coverage are not considered if the individual is already covered under specific medical care programs. The Indian Health Care Improvement Act provides a special rule for married individuals regarding the limitation on the credit under this section. The limitation is based on adjusted gross income and is reduced by a certain amount determined under paragraph (2). The limitation on the credit under the Indian Health Care Improvement Act for married individuals is based on adjusted gross income and is reduced by an amount determined under paragraph (2), which calculates the reduction based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income for the taxable year. The applicable dollar amount for exclusion from gross income under sections 911, 931, or 933 is $60,000 for taxpayers with qualified health insurance covering more than one individual, and $30,000 for others or married individuals filing separately. Marital status is determined under section 7703. Amounts not multiples of $10 are rounded down. Qualified health insurance, as defined in section 213(d), excludes coverage from group health plans and contracts with substantial benefits as excepted benefits. In the case of continuation coverage under a group health plan required by Federal law, individuals with COBRA coverage are treated as having qualified health insurance. Special rules apply, including coordination with other deductions and denial of credit to dependents. Inflation adjustment for dollar amounts in subsection (c)(3) for taxable years after 2000 is determined by multiplying the dollar amount by the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year, with a base year of 1999 instead of 1992. The text chunk discusses rounding adjustments for amounts not multiples of $100 in tax code sections. The text chunk introduces a new section on health insurance costs for previously uninsured individuals and those with COBRA coverage, with amendments effective for taxable years after December 31, 1999. It also discusses a deduction for qualified health insurance costs of employees and self-employed individuals in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The section discusses deductions for qualified health insurance costs for individuals, their spouses, and dependents. The applicable percentage for the deduction is determined according to a specified table. The applicable percentage for deductions for qualified health insurance costs is determined according to a specified table, starting at 60% in 2000 and increasing to 100% in 2004 and thereafter. A special rule applies to individuals who are employees and do not have qualified health insurance through an employer's group health plan. The tax code allows for deductions on qualified health insurance costs, with the percentage increasing from 60% in 2000 to 100% in 2004 and beyond. There are special rules for individuals without employer-provided health insurance. Additionally, there are exclusions for subsidized coverage and definitions for qualified health insurance. The tax code has special rules for individuals without employer-provided health insurance, limiting the amount of earned income that can be taken into account for deductions on qualified health insurance costs. The tax code has special rules regarding deductions for insurance payments, excluding them from medical deductions and self-employment tax calculations. Conforming amendments are made to align with these rules. The tax code has special rules for deductions related to insurance payments, including eligible long-term care premiums for qualified long-term care insurance contracts. Amendments are made to align with these rules, such as striking certain subparagraphs and adding new items for deductions allowed by section 222. The amendments made by this section relate to the costs of qualified health insurance and have an effective date for taxable years starting after December 31, 1999.
